Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Acquisition of a Gas Chromatograph with Dual Detection Capabilities to be Used in Sustainable Energy Research
Award.AbstractNarration:
With this award from the Major Research Instrumentation (MRI) and Chemistry Research Instrumentation and Facilities (CRIF) programs, the University of Kentucky acquires a gas chromatograph with dual detection capabilities: a flame ionization detector and a mass spectrometer. The system is used to separate and analyze the composition of mixtures of substances obtained from various sources including samples obtained from chemical reactions, energy-related research and batteries used for energy storage. Using this instrument, the samples are heated and then the gases are allowed to pass through columns filled with substances that interact to various degrees with the sample components and thus the components move at different speeds through the columns. This allows separation of the components. These species are analyzed using a flame ionization detector after the gases are burned to produce ions. The ions are then attracted by a polarizing electrical voltage. The current is sensed by an electrometer. In a mass spectrometer, the components are ionized and the spectrometer determines their mass by measuring the mass to charge ratio (m/z) of the ions. These are a widely used analytical tools to determine the composition of a mixture or material. Students are trained to use this instrumentation in their research, preparing them for their later careers in energy-related fields.

The instrument is used in research especially in areas such as: (a) upgrading of algal biomass to hydrocarbon fuels via catalytic hydrodeoxygenation; (b) studying the conversion of fatty acids and their derivatives to hydrocarbon fuels via decarboxylation / decarbonylation; (c) studying lignin oxidative deconstruction for the production of liquid fuels; (d) approaching nucleophilic deconstruction of lignin for the production of fuels and chemicals; (e) studying genetic engineering of algal oil synthetic biopaths into hosts capable of large-scale production; (f) evaluating different microalgae strains for the production of fuels from lignocellulosic biomass; and (g) developing battery electrolytes for high energy lithium-ion system.

Performance_Institution.Name: University of Kentucky Center for Applied Energy Research

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project supported the acquisition of a one-of-a-kind gas chromatograph with dual detection – i.e., mass spectrometry and flame ionization – capabilities, which is also uniquely designed to improve both sample homogeneity prior to injection and compound resolution during the analysis. The novel use of a splitter allows for compound separation to take place in a single column prior to dual detection. This eliminates not only the need for two separate instruments, which is the approach typically employed, but also the ambiguities in the data commonly encountered when two separate instruments are employed. While the mass spectrometer gives the user powerful information to aid in the identification of compounds, the flame ionization detector affords data that excels in their quantification. Together, the two detectors give a more complete picture not only of which components are present in the samples analyzed but also how much of each component is present.

Several lipid-based feeds and their respective biofuel products have been analyzed on the instrument, including commercial cooking oils (corn oil, canola oil, soybean oil, coconut oil), unsaturated oils (flaxseed oil, perilla, hemp oil), yellow grease (used cooking oil), and algae oil.  In addition, brown grease – an oleaginous waste material collected from grease traps that does not compete with the food supply – has also been thoroughly characterized with the use of the instrument acquired and has since become the primary focus of studies related to the catalytic upgrading of biomass to fuel-like hydrocarbons in research conducted at the University of Kentucky Center for Applied Energy Research. However, several other key studies related to the catalytic upgrading of lipids have also been made possible through the use of this instrument, including lipid profiling, mechanistic studies involving isotopically labelled compounds, as well as catalyst stability and recyclability studies. 

Notably, the versatility of the instrument has been proven though its use in the analysis of samples stemming from vastly different projects, including those related to the catalytic depolymerization of lignin. Indeed, lignin deconstruction products present a completely different analytical matrix compared to lipid-based feeds. Lignin is a complex, irregular biopolymer that gives plants their structural rigidity.  The instrument acquired has been successful in analyzing monomers, dimers and trimers obtained from lignin, which provides insights into the possibility of converting lignin to fuels and chemicals.

While this instrument has proven to be incredibly productive from a research perspective, it is also important to highlight the achievements of this project from an educational standpoint. Saliently, approximately 50 people – ranging from K-12 students to college professors (many of which belong to groups traditionally underrepresented in the sciences) – have acquired direct technical experience with the instrument and/or with data that the instrument produced. Moreover, the capabilities of this equipment have also attracted the attention of local industry.

It is also important to note that hundreds of non-technical visitors, including K-20 students, industry leaders and policy makers, tour the lab housing the equipment annually.  Audience-appropriate visual modules were developed to quickly explain the basic theory of the instrument in a way that can be understood by the general public.  Using the modules developed, the theory behind homogenizing samples, column separation, flame ionization and mass spectrometry can now be effectively and quickly explained to these visitors.


Last Modified: 08/29/2018
Modified by: Eduardo Santillan-Jimenez

POR.POR_COPY_TXT: This project supported the acquisition of a one-of-a-kind gas chromatograph with dual detection – i.e., mass spectrometry and flame ionization – capabilities, which is also uniquely designed to improve both sample homogeneity prior to injection and compound resolution during the analysis. The novel use of a splitter allows for compound separation to take place in a single column prior to dual detection. This eliminates not only the need for two separate instruments, which is the approach typically employed, but also the ambiguities in the data commonly encountered when two separate instruments are employed. While the mass spectrometer gives the user powerful information to aid in the identification of compounds, the flame ionization detector affords data that excels in their quantification. Together, the two detectors give a more complete picture not only of which components are present in the samples analyzed but also how much of each component is present. Several lipid-based feeds and their respective biofuel products have been analyzed on the instrument, including commercial cooking oils (corn oil, canola oil, soybean oil, coconut oil), unsaturated oils (flaxseed oil, perilla, hemp oil), yellow grease (used cooking oil), and algae oil. In addition, brown grease – an oleaginous waste material collected from grease traps that does not compete with the food supply – has also been thoroughly characterized with the use of the instrument acquired and has since become the primary focus of studies related to the catalytic upgrading of biomass to fuel-like hydrocarbons in research conducted at the University of Kentucky Center for Applied Energy Research. However, several other key studies related to the catalytic upgrading of lipids have also been made possible through the use of this instrument, including lipid profiling, mechanistic studies involving isotopically labelled compounds, as well as catalyst stability and recyclability studies. Notably, the versatility of the instrument has been proven though its use in the analysis of samples stemming from vastly different projects, including those related to the catalytic depolymerization of lignin. Indeed, lignin deconstruction products present a completely different analytical matrix compared to lipid-based feeds. Lignin is a complex, irregular biopolymer that gives plants their structural rigidity. The instrument acquired has been successful in analyzing monomers, dimers and trimers obtained from lignin, which provides insights into the possibility of converting lignin to fuels and chemicals. While this instrument has proven to be incredibly productive from a research perspective, it is also important to highlight the achievements of this project from an educational standpoint. Saliently, approximately 50 people – ranging from K-12 students to college professors (many of which belong to groups traditionally underrepresented in the sciences) – have acquired direct technical experience with the instrument and/or with data that the instrument produced. Moreover, the capabilities of this equipment have also attracted the attention of local industry. It is also important to note that hundreds of non-technical visitors, including K-20 students, industry leaders and policy makers, tour the lab housing the equipment annually. Audience-appropriate visual modules were developed to quickly explain the basic theory of the instrument in a way that can be understood by the general public. Using the modules developed, the theory behind homogenizing samples, column separation, flame ionization and mass spectrometry can now be effectively and quickly explained to these visitors.
